48.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I want you to think back
with me to when you first learned to ride

52.text:
a bicycle without training wheels. Do you
have the moment in your mind? I have the moment.

60.text:
I have the place. I have the time. It was
just a vivid, vivid memory for me.

66.text:
There were three of us boys and then a younger
sister. So my dad waited until I was six,

72.text:
my brother Nick was five, my brother Mike
was four and announced one Saturday morning,

78.text:
"Today we're going to learn to ride the bike
without the training wheels."

83.text:
So he took us all to a high school parking
lot about two blocks away from the house and

88.text:
said, "Lots of room. Nothing to run into.
This will be where we ride. Dan, you're first.

95.text:
You're going to ride until you fall. If you
hurt yourself, you head home. Mom will patch

100.text:
you up and send you back."
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)

103.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: So I rode for 20 or 30 seconds,
the wonderful athlete that I am, and fell

108.text:
right off the bike and skinned my knee on
the pavement. Dad gave me a hug, said, "Run

113.text:
home to Mom." So I got to Mom, and, sure enough,
she hugged me and then bandaged me.

119.text:
Now, in my house growing up, there was one
medicine for everything, Merthiolate.

125.text:
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Do you remember that nasty

128.text:
red Mercurochrome stuff, about 80 percent
alcohol, burned like you know what? I mean,

134.text:
it was just awful. She poured that on there,
put a bandage on me, gave me a hug, and sent

139.text:
me out the door. And I passed Nick coming
back.

143.text:
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And Nick had skinned up his

145.text:
left elbow.
So this went on for three hours until all

152.text:
of us had mastered riding the bicycle without
the training wheels, because my dad was willing

159.text:
to let us fall in order to teach us a lesson.
And I believe God does the exact same thing

171.text:
with us, his children. That's what we're going
to talk about today.

175.text:
I'm Dan Southerland, one of the pastors at
Westside. Turn to your neighbor and say, "You

180.text:
made a good choice to come today." Tell them.
Good choice, yeah.

185.text:
We are in this series called The Story, and
we are literally studying Genesis all the

191.text:
way through Revelation in a year's time, talking
about this love story, this redemption story

198.text:
that God wants to have relationship with us.
And today we're at a particular place. The

205.text:
title is called "The Fall." Wave your notes
at me. Do you have them? If you're watching

211.text:
online, those notes are available there too.
If you're watching at our other locations

215.text:
in Kansas City, you've got them. Follow along.
Write some things down.

220.text:
Here is the big idea for today: God will let
you fall if that's what it takes for you to

226.text:
come back into relationship with him. He is
willing to let us fall. He's willing to let

235.text:
us fail if that's what it takes to get us
to trust him again. He's willing to put us

240.text:
flat of our backs where the only direction
we could look is up if that's what it takes

248.text:
for us to want to hear from God.
Now, we've been looking at a lot of ways in

254.text:
The Story that God speaks to us. And here's
a few of them. Sometimes he speaks through

258.text:
his spirit. He just whispers something into
our soul, and we know it's God leading us.

265.text:
Sometimes he speaks through his promises,
like he did with Abraham, like he did with

270.text:
Joseph, like he did with Moses, like he did
with Samuel, the guys we've studied so far.

275.text:
He speaks through his people. Sometimes that's
through your mate or through a friend.

281.text:
I've discovered this: The older I get, the
more the voice of God sounds like the voice

287.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I don't know what's going
on with that, but I swear it is the truth.

291.text:
He speaks through his leaders. Specifically
he speaks in the Old Testament and today through

297.text:
his prophets, through people who come along
and say, "Man, you're walking away from God.

302.text:
You're falling. You're doing that slow-fade
thing that we talked about a few weeks ago.

307.text:
What's going on? Get back to going after God."
He speaks a lot of different ways. Today we're

314.text:
going to look at another way that he speaks.
He will speak through our falls and our failures

320.text:
and specifically through their consequences.
Anybody that's raised a child knows that there's

330.text:
certain lessons a kid has to learn through
consequences. Our kids are here today. We're

338.text:
thrilled to have them. One of our kids -- I
won't say which one -- learned pretty quickly

343.text:
through a consequence. You know, run into
the wall, wall hurt my head, don't think I'll

348.text:
do that again. The other of our children -- bless
her heart --

353.text:
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- had to run into the wall

357.text:
a few more times to make sure the wall was
really not going to give way.

361.text:
And here's the deal: Consequences are used
by God to teach all of us -- to teach all

369.text:
of us. I mean, we've all had to clean up some
of our own messes, and God has taught us lessons

374.text:
in that doing. So we need to understand he's
going to speak through falls, through failures,

380.text:
through consequences.
Now, we have two kings -- if you read through

383.text:
The Story this week, read your chapter, you
know that there are two amazing kings that

389.text:
are total opposites. Hezekiah is literally
called one of the godliest kings who ever

396.text:
lived. In fact, Hezekiah was so impressive
to God that God said, "I'm going to give you

402.text:
15 extra years of life. I'm going to let your
reign extend another 15 years because you

410.text:
have gone after me; you have led my people
back to me. I'm going to bless you."

416.text:
God does bless a nation according to its leaders.
Wow, that's a scary thought right now, but

422.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: It is true. But the second
thing that happens is Hezekiah has a kid named

428.text:
Manasseh. Now, problem number one: Don't name
your kid Manasseh.

432.text:
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: People, please be careful

434.text:
what you name your kids. I mean, this guy
was doomed from the start. Look at that name.

441.text:
Scripture says he did more evil than any of
the kings that had come before him. Want proof?

451.text:
Scripture gives it to us. Look at this. Manasseh
did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He rebuilt

457.text:
the high places -- that's the places of false
worship, of worship to other gods -- that

462.text:
Hezekiah had destroyed. He erected altars
to false gods. He bowed down to the stars

467.text:
and worshiped them. Look at this blasphemy.
Look at this: "He even built altars to false

474.text:
gods in the temple of the Lord." Talk about
shaking your fist in the face of God.

485.text:
Do you remember how the Hebrews had waited
literally hundreds of years to build a temple?

492.text:
And Solomon had built it, and it had a place
inside it called the Holy of Holies. Manasseh

498.text:
literally went in and said, "Ah, any God will
work. Let's put some altars to false gods

504.text:
here. You want to worship the sun, you can
do that in here." He desecrated the house

509.text:
of God. His dad was one of the godliest ever,
and he was the worst of the worst.

521.text:
And because all of this is happening, God
finally says to Manasseh and to his people,

528.text:
"Enough. You won't honor me, I'll let you
fall. You won't follow me, I'll remove my

535.text:
umbrella of protection. You won't go after
me with all your heart, I'm going to let you

544.text:
suffer the consequences of your behavior."
And an amazing thing happens: God removes

550.text:
his hand of protection. Israel is defeated,
destroyed -- and here's the big word -- taken

557.text:
into captivity.
Now, why is that a huge thing? This is the

562.text:
same people who spent 400 years as slaves
in Egypt. Remember? And God delivered them.

571.text:
And for hundreds of years they had freedom
in their own land, with their own temple,

576.text:
worshiping their own God, but because they
have turned their back on God, the Assyrians

583.text:
come, tear down the walls of the city, tear
down the temple. They leave the old and the

590.text:
crippled in Jerusalem and take everybody else
captive a thousand miles away, where they

597.text:
stay for 70 years.
This is the moment where I say to you this

604.text:
is why I fear for our nation. I haven't given
up hope, but if we continue to turn away from

614.text:
God as a nation and embrace more and more
immorality, God removes his hand of protection

622.text:
and says, "You want it? You got it."
What in the world do we learn when we blow

631.text:
it like this? What do we learn from our falls,
our failures, even from our captivity, from

637.text:
our enslavement? There are three lessons today.
Would you listen for the one that's got your

642.text:
name on it. Let's look through those three
things.

645.text:
Here's the first one. I don't like it, but
I know it's true. God is more committed to

649.text:
my character than to my comfort. I don't like
that. I kind of wish he'd be more committed

656.text:
to my comfort. But there are moments where
he will let us hurt in order to teach us a

663.text:
deeper lesson. He will let us suffer in order
to bring up part of his character inside of

670.text:
us.
Let me give a couple of examples from Mary

672.text:
and I's 40 years together. I've been a cardiac
patient for 12 years. In 2004 they discovered

681.text:
I had been out of rhythm all of my life. I
have a birth defect. The two veins that come

689.text:
together above the heart in a normal human
being form the vena cava, a big vein that

695.text:
comes into the top chamber of the heart, causes
blood to pump through. It's what keeps your

700.text:
heart in rhythm. In my body those two don't
come together above the heart. They come into

707.text:
the heart separately.
So rather than have a constant flow of blood,

713.text:
I've got a competing flow of blood. It's not
a blockage issue. It's not a cholesterol issue.

720.text:
It's not a size issue. It's nothing about
my plumbing. It is an electrical problem caused

726.text:
by a birth defect. I'm special.
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)

731.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: For 12 years I've said, "Hey,
God, you can fix this." I know he can. I've

741.text:
seen him do it. I've had 30 heart procedures
in the last 12 years. So far god hasn't fixed

750.text:
it. You know what he's done? He's taught me
to trust him at a whole new level. He's taught

762.text:
me to live every single day like it could
be the last day. He has taught me how precious

769.text:
life is, how precious relationships are, how
important people are to God.

777.text:
And I wouldn't swap what I have learned for
being healed. He's been more committed to

784.text:
my character than to my comfort.
My wife sitting here on the front row with

788.text:
our son and daughter-in-law and daughter and
son-in-law and friends from south Florida

792.text:
-- it's like reunion week going over here.
In fact, let's just stop. You want to? No,

800.text:
let's not stop.
My wife has had back trouble for 35 years.

807.text:
Injured her back 35 years ago. She has hurt
every day of her life for 35 years. The question

814.text:
is not "Does your back hurt today?" The question
is, "What level? Is it a 3, a 5, or a 10?"

819.text:
I mean, I say to her all the time, "What number?"
She gets tired of that question, but that

823.text:
tells me where are we.
I have asked God, as I know she has, "Lord,

828.text:
you could heal this." But do you know how
sensitive he's made her to people that are

833.text:
in pain? Do you know how much faith she has
learned? Do you know how tough she has become?

840.text:
God allows some trouble, some hurt, some pain
in order to develop our character because

846.text:
there's some things we won't learn any other
way.

850.text:
Turn to your neighbor and say, "You are certainly
part of my character development." Go ahead

857.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Don't tell them they're a
pain. Yeah.

859.text:
All right. So here's what I want you to write
down. Are you ready? There's a blank here

863.text:
that only you can fill in: "A lesson I learned
the hard way." One lesson in life you learned

869.text:
the hard way.
Maybe it was an addiction. Maybe it was a

873.text:
lifestyle. Maybe it was a broken relationship.
Maybe it was a parenting mistake, a financial

878.text:
mistake. Something you learned the hard way,
and God let your falling and your failure

884.text:
and your consequences teach you a lesson.
Have you got one? If you don't, hang on. It's

890.text:
coming. Hang on. It's coming. Sometimes God
teaches us because he's more committed to

896.text:
our character than to our comfort.
Number 2: God will let me fail on my own -- that's

903.text:
the big phrase -- in order to teach me to
follow him. He will let me fail on my own.

914.text:
One of the problems we face in the Western
Hemisphere but even worse in America, and

919.text:
I think even worse for men -- I hate to admit
this -- is the "I can do it myself" syndrome.

926.text:
You been around a two- or a three-year-old
lately? "I do it myself. I do it myself. I

933.text:
do it myself."
I think we tell God that all the time. All

937.text:
the time. We say things like, "I'm going to
be a better husband." If you could be a better

942.text:
husband, you'd already be one. You can't.
"I'm going to do a better job of parenting."

948.text:
I doubt it.
"I'm going to lose weight." How is that working

954.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: We got to change the pronoun.
We got to make it, "Jesus, help me be a better

962.text:
husband. Jesus, make me a new parent. Jesus,
teach me healthier ways to live. Jesus" -- it's

971.text:
this "I can't, God can, join him" idea that
we've talked about so many times. We try to

980.text:
do things on our own, and we are going to
set ourselves up for failure and for falling.

985.text:
Now, by the way, sometimes you have success
for a while before you fail. I remember in

991.text:
south Florida -- it's fun, Allen, that you
and Sharon are here today.

995.text:
I had come to Flamingo Road Church and been
there a couple of years and, wow, things are

1001.text:
going like crazy. Crazy. We were doing two
services Saturday night, three Sunday morning,

1007.text:
two Sunday night. Seven services a weekend.
And I was dumb enough back then to do about

1013.text:
90 percent of the teaching. I was about to
learn to share it. I had an S on my chest

1018.text:
that I thought stood for Superman. Any S on
your chest stands for stupid.

1023.text:
CONGREGATION: (Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: In any area of life where

1026.text:
you think you're Superman, you are stupid.
I'll never forget: About three years into

1033.text:
that schedule, my health just crashed. Had
the flu through Christmas. Couldn't get over

1039.text:
it. Lost my voice. Saw my doctor. Saw a vocal
specialist who said to me, "You have nodes

1048.text:
on your vocal cords. If you don't be silent
for the next four weeks, you're not going

1055.text:
to be able to continue to speak."
I said, "No problem. I'll whisper."

1061.text:
He said, "Whispering is worse. You cannot
speak at all for four weeks." He did not realize

1071.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: You tell a Southerland to
not speak for four weeks? Now, this is before

1075.text:
the days of texting. Because I could have
just texted everything, you know. Like, "Hey,"

1079.text:
or "When are we going to eat?" I'm writing
stuff -- I carried a yellow pad for four weeks.

1085.text:
We went out of town for the biggest part of
that time. We got away.

1089.text:
And during that time, sitting out on a porch
in Naples, Florida, one afternoon, I heard

1094.text:
God whisper in my soul, "When are you going
to stop doing this by yourself? When are you

1107.text:
going to let me in?"
He will absolutely let me fail on my own in

1115.text:
order to teach me to follow him, in order
to teach me to partner with him, in order

1121.text:
to teach me to do life with him.
Third one -- would you write it down -- God

1126.text:
is always wanting to grow me to be more like
his son, Jesus.

1131.text:
Now, there's a lot of things God has in mind
for you. Let me give you some. God wants you

1137.text:
to be joyful. That's awesome. But even more
than that, he's committed to you being like

1142.text:
Jesus.
God wants to bless you. That's incredible.

1145.text:
Even more than that, he's committed to you
being like Jesus.

1149.text:
God wants to use you in ministry and to give
you a place and a purpose to count for him.

1156.text:
Whoo! That's good stuff. But even more than
that, he's committed to making your character

1164.text:
more like Jesus, whatever it takes.
Michelangelo was easily the greatest artist

1175.text:
of his time. Had skills all the way from painting
big things, like the ceiling of the chapel,

1182.text:
all the way to sculpture. It's a wide array
of gifts for an artist.

1187.text:
And he was asked on his most famous sculpture,
the sculpture of David -- I think it's cool

1195.text:
that Michelangelo picked a Biblical character
for his prize -- prize production. He was

1202.text:
asked, "How do you take a block of rock and
sculpture it into something that's beautiful?

1210.text:
How do you do it?"
And here's what he said: "I get the image

1215.text:
in my mind of David, and I chip away everything
that doesn't look like him."

1224.text:
You know what Jesus is doing? He's chipping
away everything that doesn't look like him.

1234.text:
Will he let you fail to do it? Yeah. Doesn't
bother him at all. Will he let you fall to

1241.text:
teach you to ride this spiritual bicycle?
Absolutely. Will he let consequences pile

1247.text:
up in your life? Yes. If you keep running
into the wall, it will keep hurting your head.

1252.text:
Because he's committed to us becoming like
Jesus. He did this with an entire nation,

1263.text:
said, "You-all want to dishonor me again,
I'll let you go back to slavery until you

1269.text:
cry out to me, until you come back to relationship
with me."

1274.text:
So here's the big idea for today, kind of
rewritten in a different format. Would you

1280.text:
write this in. Until I come to the end of
myself, I cannot know the fullness of Christ.

1292.text:
The Hebrews had gotten proud in their hundreds
of years of being king. They had become proud

1298.text:
of being the most adored city, the place in
the Mediterranean that everybody came -- the

1305.text:
power, the beauty, the riches of their nation.
Sound familiar?

1312.text:
And God said, "I'll do what it takes to get
you to come back." Why does he do that? Check

1319.text:
out a great verse in Jeremiah, one of my favorite
verses. By the way, we quote this promise

1325.text:
all the time. We never read the conditions
that come after it. It's always interesting

1330.text:
how we do that. We pull the part of the Bible
we like and we quote it, but we ignore the

1336.text:
conditions of the promise.
Listen to what God says through the profit

1340.text:
Jeremiah, who, by the way, gave this prophesy
at the exact moment they were being taken

1346.text:
into captivity. As they're being hauled away
to slavery, Jeremiah says, "For I know the

1354.text:
plans I have for you, declares the Lord, plans
not to harm you. Plans to prosper you, plans

1362.text:
to give you hope and a future."
Seriously, Jeremiah? We're being carted off

1368.text:
into captivity, and you're talking about hope
and promise and future? Seriously? They were

1374.text:
so pleased with Jeremiah, they sawed him in
half.

1379.text:
But listen to the condition in the next verse
that came with it: "When you call on me, and

1388.text:
come and pray to me, I will listen to you.
When you seek me with all your heart, I will

1396.text:
be found by you, declares the Lord, and will
bring you back from captivity."

1406.text:
Translation: How long you're in slavery is
up to you. How long you're in captivity, it's

1416.text:
up to you. You come after me with your whole
heart, I will set you free. You need another

1424.text:
400-year lesson, I'm game.
Good news is it only took 70 years -- two

1433.text:
generations -- for them to come back to God.
But here's where I want to go, guys: All of

1440.text:
us are dealing with some level of captivity:
some habit, some piece of our character, some

1449.text:
piece of our lives that is unsurrendered.
And the reality is God will let us fall, fail,

1457.text:
deal with consequence until we surrender it.
So here's the last two things I want to say

1463.text:
to you, and then we got a video to demonstrate
this very truth. Jesus wants to bring you

1468.text:
home. That's his heart. His heart was not
to send them to Babylon to be in captivity.

1476.text:
His heart was to bring them home. And he wants
to set you free. It's an amazing thing what

1483.text:
God can do when we surrender.
Westside has been trying to surrender to God

1492.text:
in what our role is in global impact for the
last several years. And while we've got church

1499.text:
planting going in South Africa, in India,
in Thailand, we've got it going nowhere like

1506.text:
it's going in Laos. We have stepped into the
middle of a God thing.

1511.text:
I want you to meet Pastor Ed. Now, it's going
to say Isra for his name, but he says Americans

1517.text:
can't say Isra; so we call him Ed. He's a
maniac for Jesus. There are amazing God things

1525.text:
happening in these new church plants in Laos.
I want you to hear it from Ed himself. Check

1594.text:
ROB WEGNER: Three years ago, a small team
from Westside came here to the great nation of Thailand,

1598.text:
and they gathered with some indigenous
leaders who had a dream of reaching their

1602.text:
nation, of seeing a movement of new disciples
of Jesus who would care for the physical and

1608.text:
spiritual orphan. And out of that gathering,
that dream has begun to be realized.

1614.text:
JASON MORRIS: We're experiencing miracles
very much like what you find in the first

1619.text:
parts of the New Testament, where people are
getting first contact with the gospel and

1634.text: ROB WEGNER: From that short time of training,

1637.text:
a movement has spilled out of that room. And
over the last three years -- get this -- there's

1642.text:
more than 130 new churches. Over 6,000 men
and women and boys and girls have been baptized.

1648.text:
Hundreds of orphans are being cared for. This
literally sounds like a story ripped out of

1652.text:
the pages of Acts, and it's happening right
here, right now. And guess what? At this very

1657.text:
moment, this story's going to a whole new
level.

1659.text:
JASON MORRIS: One of these particular stories
that we've heard from one of the villages

1664.text:
is a particular witch doctor who was being
oppressed by the very demon that he was using

1688.text: And he had heard that there were people that

1690.text: were reaching villages telling him about Jesus.

1693.text: And so he invited Pastor Samsuk to come and

1696.text: tell him and the village about Jesus.

1702.text: And a little bit later his whole family came

1705.text:
to know Jesus, and a week later the entire
village came to know Jesus.

1722.text:
One of the ways that they symbolize their
allegiance to the particular demon that they

1728.text:
serve is they have these little white bracelets
that bind them to that particular demon.

1757.text:
And so they had this huge ceremony where they
began to cut off all of the bracelets to symbolize

1762.text:
their freedom not only from sin and death
and hell but freedom from the very demon

1773.text: ROB WEGNER: Westside is helping the best and the brightest in this movement

1776.text:
to be equipped to be
trainers and coaches.

1779.text:
In other words, there's a movement that's 
already gone to multiplication.

1782.text: We have disciples who are making disciples.

1784.text:
We have churches that are
planting churches.

1786.text: But now we're going to put a multiplication sign

1809.text:
JASON MORRIS: And so it's, like, 
Okay. Let's do this.

1812.text:
You know, we'll just trust just like
in the book of Acts, just like in the Bible,

1850.text: he sensed the power of God

1852.text:
in that prayer, and the boy began to
walk.

1892.text:
Those types of miracles happen because of
the trainings that we here at Westside -- you allow

1897.text:
us to do those sorts of things, to bring
the gospel to places where they've never heard

1902.text:
it before and are desperately asking for it
and need it like we can't even imagine.

1908.text:
ROB WEGNER: And it's happening right here
and right now because the people of Westside

1912.text:
have said yes to Jesus, because the people
of Westside have said, "God, use us to reach

1918.text:
the physical and spiritual orphan." 
And it's happening. And it's amazing.

1950.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: For 2,000 years, every time
the gospel goes into a new nation, a new people group,

1956.text:
a new corner of the earth where it's never been
shared before, the miraculous always takes place.

1963.text:
It's God's way of saying,
"I validate this."

1969.text:
And we are not surprised that this is happening
in Laos. It's a country of 7 million people.

1975.text:
Less than 2 percent are Christ followers.
The vast majority of Laotians have never even

1983.text:
heard of Jesus, and yet God has blessed with
130-plus churches, 6,000-plus baptisms, people

1994.text:
coming to Christ, and I think it is hilarious
that more Westsiders speak Lao than speak

2001.text:
English. That's a God thing.
You are part of that. This doesn't happen

2009.text:
without your giving, without your praying,
without your believing, without your blessing.

2016.text:
Thank you.
God is determined to continue to use us to

2023.text:
reach the spiritual and physical orphans of
the world.

2026.text:
Here is my blessing as we go. May we all learn
from our falls and our failures and our consequences,

2035.text:
and may we learn quickly. Amen?
CONGREGATION: Amen.

2040.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Prayer partners are down
front.
